thread.title: Wolfpack preparing for tough ACC opener
thread.title_full: Wolfpack preparing for tough ACC opener

title: Wolfpack preparing for tough ACC opener
text:
Wolfpack preparing for tough ACC opener 
Posted 4:15 p.m. yesterday Your friends e-mail addresses (comma separated): * Subject: * You must enter the characters with black color that stand out from the other characters More on this 
Samuels: I don't know if he's playing or not By Marilyn Payne 
Raleigh, N.C. — When NC State hosts Louisville Saturday in its ACC opener, the Wolfpack knows it will face a battle-tested and talented Cardinal team despite the visitors’ record. 
“I know their record is 1-3, but we’re not going to look at it like that.” fullback Jaylen Samuels said. “We know that they’re going to be a very good team no matter what when ACC (play) comes.” 
Louisville’s three losses have all come by seven points or fewer, and two of the losses were against Top 10 opponents (No. 6 Auburn and No. 9 Clemson). 
NC State remembers well the 30-18 loss to Louisville last year and still identifies this season’s Cardinal team as being strong, even though Louisville is significantly younger this season than it was last year. 
Head coach Dave Doeren recognizes that his own undefeated team is still young, though he hopes the ACC experience his players do have will benefit them in this week’s conference opener. 
“We’re more experienced,” Doeren said. “Last year’s team was extremely young. While we’re still young, we at least have guys that played a lot in ACC games last year.” 
One of the Wolfpack’s biggest areas of growth since losing to Louisville in 2014 is in its ability to finish games. This week, and every week from here on out, Doeren knows his team’s ability to play every minute of the game is going to be of the highest importance. 
“We’ve lost our ACC opener the last two seasons to Clemson and Florida State,” Doeren said. “I think last year they learned how to finish as the year went on. When you get into conference play, that’s what you’re going to have are four-quarter games.” 
If NC State’s offensive consistency is indicative of its ability to finish a full game, the Pack will continue to be just fine. 
NC State boasts an offense with the nation’s most efficient quarterback – Jacoby Brisett has completed 77.9 percent of his passes this season – and one of the nation’s highest-scoring running backs -- Matt Dayes is tied for first with nine rushing touchdowns. 
For an offense that has been both productive and efficient in every game this season, the main threat against the statistically strong NC State offense is the Cardinals secondary. 
“We’re excited to play a really, really good defense,” offensive coordinator Matt Canada said. (They have) one of the best defenses in the country and (are) s team that certainly got after us last year. 
“For this to be our first ACC game, our opener, I think we’re very excited,” Samuels said. “It’s a good defense, they have a lot of ball hawks in the secondary, they’re very physical and they’ve got a lot of speed.” 
Louisville’s offense has turned the ball over 10 times this season, but on the opposite side of the ball, the Cardinals defense is in a four-way first place tie for most interceptions in the nation with nine, posing a threatening stat against Brissett’s no interceptions season. The defensive line is a force, making week one of ACC play a true test for NC State, regardless of the dearth of wins on Louisville’s record. 
“Obviously we’re aware that we’re starting conference play, that’s real,” Canada said. “We know we’re playing a great team that has a great defense that has challenged and stopped the majority of the teams they’ve played. So, we’ve got a tremendous challenge.” Credits
